description: América Móvil made a slight improvement to its disclosure of policies affecting users’ freedom of expression by publishing an archive of some previous terms of service policies, enabling users to see and understand changes to the terms of service over time (F2). Read América Móvil’s report card for more.
name: América Móvil

description:
Apple earned the largest score improvement of any company in the 2018 Index. Notably, the company strengthened its public commitment to protecting users’ privacy as a human right (G1), although no such commitment could be found regarding users’ freedom of expression.

Apple also improved its disclosure of how it handles government requests to restrict accounts (F5, F6). In the Privacy category, the company improved its disclosure of options users have to control how their information is used for targeted advertising (P7), and about how users can obtain a copy of their user information (P8). The company also clarified its policies for responding to data breaches, and was the only internet and mobile ecosystem category company to receive any credit on this indicator (P15). Read Apple’s report card for more.
name: Apple

description: AT&T improved its disclosure of how it responds to network shutdown demands from governments (F10), and its disclosure of options users have to access their own user data (P8). However, the company’s score in the Governance category declined due to its weakened commitment to engage with stakeholders on freedom of expression and privacy issues (G5). AT&T did not join the Global Network Initiative (GNI) after the Telecommunications Industry Dialogue became inactive in 2017. Read AT&T’s report card for more.
name: AT&T

description: Axiata’s freedom of expression score declined due to a change in its disclosure of notification policies for prepaid users, with the terms of service stating that the company can restrict an account without prior notice (F8). However, the company’s privacy score increased slightly due to improved disclosure of its internal security oversight processes (P13). Read Axiata’s report card for more.
name: Axiata

description: Baidu improved its governance score by publishing a commitment to protect user privacy (G1), and it improved its disclosure of grievance and remedy mechanisms (G6). The company also made key improvements to its disclosure of policies affecting users’ privacy: It improved its disclosure of its policies for notifying users of privacy policy changes (P2); provided more detailed information about the purpose for collecting and sharing user information (P5); improved its disclosure of what de-identified user information it retains (P6); and it clarified options users have control how some of their information is used for targeted advertising (P7), although this suggests that targeted advertising is on by default. Read Baidu’s report card for more.
name: Baidu

description: Bharti Airtel improved its governance score by providing information about employee training on security issues, but it was not clear if this training covers broader privacy issues (G3). The company also improved its disclosure of its internal security oversight processes by explaining how it monitors employee access to user information (P13). However, the company lost points for its less clear disclosure of its network management policies and practices (F9). Read Bharti Airtel’s report card for more.
name: Bharti Airtel

description: Etisalat made a slight improvement to its policies affecting users privacy by clarifying it has security teams in place to monitor the company’s networks to identify and mitigate privacy and security threats (P13). Read Etisalat’s report card for more.
name: Etisalat

description: Facebook improved its disclosure of its terms of service enforcement by providing more information about the methods it uses to identify terms of service violations (F3), and it disclosed some data on the volume and nature of actions it took to enforce its rules (F4). The company also improved its disclosure of how it handles both government and private requests to restrict content or user accounts (F5), and provided more data about its compliance with private requests to remove content (F7). In the privacy category, the company improved its disclosure of its processes for responding to government requests for user information (P10). In addition, Facebook improved its disclosure about account security by rolling out two-factor authentication for Instagram and WhatsApp (P17). Read Facebook’s report card for more.
name: Facebook

description: Google improved its disclosure of options users have to control some of the information the company collects about them (P7), and it disclosed more information about how and why it tracks users of its Android mobile ecosystem across the internet (P9). Read the company’s report card for more. Read Google’s report card for more.
name: Google

description: Kakao improved its disclosure of options for users of KakaoTalk to control how their user information is used for targeted advertising (P7), although this suggests that targeted advertising is on by default. Read Kakao’s report card for more.
name: Kakao

description: Mail.Ru made no changes that resulted in score changes in the 2018 Index. Read Mail.Ru’s report card for more.
name: Mail.Ru

description: While leading most internet and mobile ecosystem companies in the Index, Microsoft’s overall score declined slightly due to less clear disclosure of whether it notifies Skype users of account restrictions (F8). However, the company’s governance score improved due to improved disclosure of whether it assesses privacy risks associated with enforcing its terms of service (G4). Read Microsoft’s report card for more.
name: Microsoft

description: MTN improved its commitment to conducting human rights due diligence, stating it concluded its first human rights impact assessment (HRIA) evaluating the freedom of expression and privacy risks associated with MTN products and services (G4). However, the company’s disclosure of its process for responding to requests for user information declined. While MTN previously disclosed information on how it carries out due diligence on government and private requests for user information, researchers could not locate similar commitments in current policy documents (P10). Read MTN’s report card for more.
name: MTN

description: Ooredoo made no changes that resulted in score changes in the 2018 Index. Read Ooredoo’s report card for more.
name: Ooredoo

description: Orange improved its commitment to engage with stakeholders by joining the Global Network Initiative (GNI) (G5), and also improved its disclosure of its human rights due diligence practices by clarifying that it conducts human rights impacts assessments on a regular basis (G4). In the Freedom of Expression category, Orange improved its transparency of its handling of government network shutdown demands by disclosing an example in which it pushed back on such a request (F10). It also improved its disclosure of policies affecting users’ privacy, including by clarifying users’ options to download a copy of their data that the company holds on them (P8). The company also improved its disclosure of its internal security oversight policies, clearly stating it conducts audits on its products and services (P13). Read Orange’s report card for more.
name: Orange

description: Samsung made several key improvements in the 2018 Index. The company improved its disclosure of senior leadership over policies and practices that affect freedom of expression and privacy (G2), and it disclosed new information about conducting human rights impact assessments (HRIAs) related to privacy risks (G4). Samsung also improved its privacy score by clarifying how it directly notifies users of changes to privacy policies (P2), and by improving its disclosure related to how it handles user information after a user’s account is terminated (P6). Notably, the company provided users with more options to control over how their user information is used for targeted advertising (P7), although this suggests that targeted advertising is on by default. However, its disclosure also became less clear about whether it combines user information across services (P5). Read Samsung’s report card for more.
name: Samsung

description: Telefónica improved its commitment to engaging with stakeholders by joining the Global Network Initiative (GNI) (G5), and it provided more detailed information about its the process for responding to privacy and freedom of expression-related complaints (G6). The company also made a clearer commitment to push back on overbroad government requests for content and account restrictions (F5), provided more detailed data on its compliance with such requests (F6), and improved its disclosure of how it responds to network shutdown demands (F10). Telefónica also improved its disclosure of how it handles government demands for user information (P10, P11). Read Telefónica’s report card for more.
name: Telefónica

description: Tencent made WeChat’s privacy policy easier to find (P1), and clarified its policies for notifying users when that policy changes (P2). It also provided more comprehensive information about the purpose for collecting users’ information (P5), and improved its disclosure of options WeChat users have to control what information the company collects and of how they can delete some of their information (P7). Tencent also improved its disclosure of its security oversight processes by clarifying that it restricts employee access to user information (P13). Read Tencent’s report card for more.
name: Tencent

description: Twitter’s overall score improved despite weakening its disclosure of policies affecting users’ privacy. The company made several improvements in the Governance category, including by clarifying its human rights due diligence practices (G4). Twitter’s freedom of expression score increased due to improved disclosure of its process for responding to government and private requests to remove content or restrict account restrictions (F5, F6). However, Twitter’s privacy score declined due to revisions to its privacy policy that made the company’s handling of user information less clear. In particular, the policy lacked clarity about the purposes for which the company tracks users on third-party websites and for how long it retains this information (P9). It also revealed it no longer respects “Do Not Track” signals from users telling the company not to track them across the web (P9). Read Twitter’s report card for more.
name: Twitter

description: Vodafone strengthened its commitment to engage with stakeholders (G5) by joining the Global Network Initiative (GNI), and improved its disclosure of its human rights due diligence practices (G4). Vodafone also improved its disclosure of how it responds to government network shutdown orders (F10). The company significantly improved its disclosure of policies for responding to data breaches (P15). However, Vodafone lost points in the 2018 Index for not specifying whether it notifies users who attempt to access content that it has been restricted (F8). Read Vodafone’s report card for more.
name: Vodafone

description: Oath improved its disclosure of how it handles government and private requests to restrict content or accounts (F5) and to hand over user information (P11). It also clarified its policies regarding whether it notifies users if it restricts their account (F8). It improved its disclosure of options Tumblr users have to opt-out of targeted advertising (P7), although this suggests that targeted advertising is on by default. However, Oath’s transparency regarding its human rights due diligence processes (G4) declined slightly since the 2017 Index, due to less clear disclosure of whether its human rights impact assessments (HRIAs) are incorporated into executive- or board-level decisions. Read Oath’s report card for more.
name: Oath

description: Yandex made no changes that resulted in score changes in the 2018 Index. Read Yandex’s report card for more.
name: Yandex
